elements.title: Myanmar Photo Archive (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Myanmar Photo Archive (example photograph shown) revealed "a side of modern Myanmar that, until very recently, remained hidden in dusty attics"?

elements.title: Judi Singh (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that jazz singer Judi Singh's mother and father were, respectively, among the earliest Black and Sikh settlers of Alberta, Canada?

elements.title: Elmwood Tower (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Elmwood Tower may have once been the tallest building in Omaha?

elements.title: R. Ames Montgomery (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that R. Ames Montgomery resigned as president of Centre College after students petitioned to remove him for de-emphasizing football?

elements.title: Selfish (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Britney Spears's 2011 song "Selfish" reached number one on the iTunes chart in 2024?

elements.title: Chen Xue (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that despite a career writing queer literature, Chen Xue's 2019 novel Fatherless City had a "putatively straight premise"?

elements.title: Weird Faith (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that singer-songwriter Madi Diaz released her sixth studio album, Weird Faith, after touring with Harry Styles?

elements.title: Kate Gleason (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Kate Gleason would wear her most feminine attire available as a strategy to sell bevel gears?

elements.title: Walter Abel Heurtley (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Alan Wace recruited Walter Abel Heurtley, a former military prison governor, to help manage the students of the British School at Athens?
